[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker supply a malicious output_path like '../../../etc/passwd' or '/etc/shadow' to overwrite critical system files when the write() function is called with user-controlled paths? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Path Traversal] Does the write() method validate that output_path doesn't contain directory traversal sequences like '..', './', or absolute paths that could escape intended output directories and overwrite validator configuration files? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Struct: OutputArgs] [Path Validation] Is there any sanitization or canonicalization of the output_path field before it's used in std::fs::write(), or can attackers use encoded traversal sequences like '%2e%2e%2f' to bypass basic filters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Symlink Attack] If output_path points to a symbolic link, does std::fs::write() follow the symlink, potentially allowing an attacker to create a symlink pointing to /var/lib/aptos/config.yaml and overwrite validator configuration when the tool runs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [File Overwrite] Does write() check if the target file already exists and validate permissions before overwriting, or can it silently overwrite critical node-checker baseline configuration files causing validator health check failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Directory Creation] If output_path specifies a file in a non-existent directory like '/tmp/nonexistent/output.yaml', does std::fs::write() fail safely or could this cause panic/crash in production node-checker deployments? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Absolute Path Bypass] Can an attacker specify an absolute path like '/root/.ssh/authorized_keys' as output_path to write arbitrary content to system-critical locations when node-checker runs with elevated privileges? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Struct: OutputArgs] [Path Length] Is there validation on the length of output_path to prevent buffer overflow attacks or filesystem path length limits (4096 bytes on Linux) that could cause truncation and write to unintended locations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Null Byte Injection] Can output_path contain null bytes ('\0') that could truncate the path in underlying C FFI calls, causing the file to be written to a different location than intended? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Special Characters] Are special characters in output_path like newlines, tabs, or control characters properly validated to prevent filesystem manipulation or log injection attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [TOCTOU Race] Is there a race condition between when output_path is validated (if at all) and when std::fs::write() is called, allowing an attacker to swap a legitimate file with a symlink to critical validator keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Concurrent Writes] If multiple node-checker instances run simultaneously with the same output_path, can this cause file corruption, partial writes, or race conditions that lead to malformed OpenAPI specs being served? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Atomic Writes] Does std::fs::write() perform atomic writes, or can partial writes occur if the process crashes mid-write, potentially corrupting node-checker configuration files? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Permission Check] Does write() verify the process has write permissions to the target path before attempting to write, or does it rely on std::fs::write() error handling which might fail silently in some scenarios? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Umask Bypass] What file permissions are set when creating new files through std::fs::write()? Can an attacker exploit weak default permissions (e.g., world-writable) to modify node-checker output files after creation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Privilege Escalation] If node-checker runs with elevated privileges (root/sudo), can output_path be exploited to write files with elevated permissions, potentially creating setuid binaries or modifying system configs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Struct: OutputArgs] [Cross-User Access] In multi-user systems, can one user specify output_path in another user's home directory to leak sensitive node-checker results or overwrite their configurations? (Medium)

Can an attacker cause the write() function to fill up disk space by generating massive OpenAPI specs, causing validator node failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Memory Exhaustion] Does write() handle extremely large output strings efficiently, or can passing gigabytes of data in the output parameter cause memory exhaustion and node-checker crashes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Infinite Loop] Can maliciously crafted output_path values (e.g., device files like /dev/random) cause write() to hang indefinitely, blocking node-checker execution? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/ecosystem/node-checker/src/common/common_args.rs] [Function: write()] [Device File Write] Can output_path point to special device files like /dev/null, /dev/zero, /dev/urandom causing unexpected behavior or resource consumption when std::fs::write() attempts to write to them?
